text: We see flashes of memory. A balloon in trouble. A man * falling. * Glints of sunlight through an ominous grey sky. * AMELIA WREN, late 20s with a hazardous expression, sits behind the window of a fast moving carriage. She’s lookin at the sky - and there’s pain mirrored in her eyes. *
Stop the carriage. She bangs hard on the roof.
Stop the carriage. The carriage is pulled to a stop.

AMELIA gets out of the carriage - she tumbles out in her to dismount with speed. She stands on the dirty street. S tries to recover her composure. ANTONIA, her caring siste gets out of the carriage behind her. On-screen title: LONDON, 1862. *
Amelia, are you quite well? AMELIA looks at her.
You don’t need to fly today. Return to Richmond with me...
Antonia, I just need a moment.
With all you've been through... No- one would think worse of you....
I would. I would think worse of me. * I made an agreement with Mr * Glaisher. *
You barely know the man! And the *
little you do know, you’re irritated by. *  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 3
Antonia, please, just give me a moment. ANTONIA frowns and nods.

Last piece of sisterly advice - doubt is there to be listened to. She re-enters the carriage. AMELIA looks up at the sky. She thinks. She lies back on pavement, she takes a moment. A man walks by and tuts disapprovingly, but AMELIA doesn’ care. She looks up, ever up, and then she smiles.
Behind AMELIA, in the back of shot, we see A BOY RUNNING ALONG THE STREET.

And now we’re with the 9 year old, a boot black in unifor as he runs, this is CHARLIE. He runs alongside dilapidate slum terraced houses. He has a look of intensity on his f He approaches an intersection of busy streets. Filled wit carts, carriages, cows and horses. He runs straight acros causing a carriage and a cart to take evasive action.

oi! CHARLIE stops and turns, he dances this way and then danc that. A smile on his face. COACHMAN (CONT’D) You little... CHARLIE runs on. On the other side of the road, he runs alongside a long q of people beside a wooden fence. He runs through and past them all. He sees what he’s look for - a big sign ‘HISTORY MADE. HERE. TODAY. HOW HIGH CAN THEY GO?” Above the sign sits a painted picture of a gas balloon.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 4

The Widow Wren takes to the skies to break the world record. Get your tickets! Next to the sign is a tall hedgerow. CHARLIE checks that not being watched, and then he ducks down through a gap i the hedge, pushes through a hole in the fence behind, and sneaks into the Gardens.

Everywhere there are hordes of people - all moving in one direction. There’s an air of anticipation and the chatter excitement. CHARLIE weaves and dodges, passing food sellers, Waveswingers, Revolving Chairs and Merry-Go-Rounds - stal and entertainment all put on to make the most of the occa (and maximize the money taken). But CHARLIE runs through all, determined. Until he gets to the only thing he wants to see - the onl thing everyone wants to see - he looks up in awe towards: An enormous red and white striped, silk air balloon. Bigg better, bolder than the picture on the sign. 93,000 cubic feet, 80 feet tall, and 55 feet wide, covere a vast rope webbing... It towers over the top of the fair This is the MAMMOTH. It is unlike any gas balloon you’ve seen. And it is magnificent. Charlie’s mouth gapes open, and then he smiles.

And we travel past CHARLIE, towards the balloon, it rests the centre of an amphitheatre type structure, filled with VAST CROWDS that have gathered to see the balloon rise. Around the circumference of the balloon, 16 men hold guid ropes to keep the Mammoth in place, with further ropes ti to stakes in the earth. The basket has a temporary platfo surrounding it.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 5

We settle on a man in the basket of the balloon stowing a series of instruments and trying to ignore the fact that is at the centre of all the attention. This is JAMES GLAISHER, 35, a man whose forensic attention to detail be the adventurer within. He looks at his pocket watch, irritated, and then checks rechecks that the bindings on one of his barometers are securely fastened - a job he’s clearly done a hundred tim already this morning. Another man, JOHN TREW, bookish and loyal, ascends the temporary wooden steps to the platform.
She's late.
She is, but that is the least of your problems.
We'll lose the light...
James, do the clouds not look ominous to you? But JAMES doesn’t look at the clouds, he’s consumed, he climbs out of the basket and checks his watch.

I repeatedly explained the importance of catching the right light and the right wind at the right time and - JAMES turns to his bag, he begins to check further instruments inside. Amongst them we see a compass, two thermometers (a “dry” and a “wet” one, which is wrapped i muslin and submerged in water), a spectroscope, a magnet, barometer, and a hygrometer.
James. Look up. JAMES looks up. He sees the dark clouds, he frowns.

Not a concern, John, the readings I took this morning were quite clear that...  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 He bends to another basket. He puts some feed into it. pigeons inside coo appreciatively.
Far be it from me to doubt you, but your weather predictions have been wrong in the past and it’s just possible...
Don’t even think of it. The NED is a tall bald man with a dour face. JAMES looks at h and smiles to mask a grimace.

Ned Chambers, John Trew, my very good friend. John this is Ned, one of the hardy entrepreneurs who has invested in our expedition - JOHN leans down from the platform to shake NED’s hand. Bu NED pays him no attention, he ascends the stairs to the platform, looming over JAMES ominously.
Don’t even think of telling me flight is not possible.
Mr Chambers, we are scientists of the air, and we can tell you the one thing no-one can control is - well - the air -
I have paid for gas, I have paid for silk - and is this balloon not the strongest and largest that’s ever been?
But even so it can’t fight the weather, you do not want to be responsible for a tragedy, Sir.
I don’t wish to be responsible for refunding the ten thousand who've come here ‘cause you promised them history and -—
(cutting in) We'll fly, Ned. We’ll fly.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 7 JOHN TREW looks at his friend concerned, NED smiles. JAME GLAISHER meets eyes with NED.
We only need the sky to hold for ninety minutes - once we’re above the cloud line, it will be fine.
Good. That's fixed. Now - did you not promise me a five o’clock ascent?
I did. I am merely waiting for the pilot. It’s not the first time she's kept me waiting. NED smiles and walks away through the crowds. JAMES watch him go and then looks up anxiously at the clouds.
What a truly pleasant man - JAMES - deliberately not looking up - starts to load a se of sample jars into the balloon, wrapping each one in cot and then placing them into the case.
One must make compromises in order to achieve greatness my friend.... He hears a ROAR from the crowds, he turns towards it, as JAMES.
And he’s merely one compromise.

Fast approaching, standing on top of a carriage drawn by horses - getting cheers from all sides - AMELIA is now resplendent in a dress festooned with feathers. It’s a complete transformation from the woman we saw earlier, th woman almost cowed by the world is now wild and fabulous. has the crowd in the palm of her hand and has a look of u delight on her face. As the carriage pulls alongside the balloon, one of the m holding the ropes passes one to her. She SWINGS from it o the rostrum. She does a cartwheel on landing, and turns t cartwheel into a flip. She lands, and presents to the cro
You're incredibly late.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 8

Lesson number one of Aeronauting- we are creatures of the skies and have no respect for landlocked clocks. She walks around to the steps leading to the basket, and speaks loud enough for everyone to hear her.
Mr. Glaisher, are you really not a gentlemen at all? Hold out your hand to me. JAMES holds out his hand. She takes it. And then she tumb from the steps into his arms.
Naughty. The crowd cheers. NED pushes through the crowd to see her, AMELIA smiles at beguilingly.
Are you ready?
Mr Glaisher, you have no conception of how ready I am. NED smiles at her shyly. She gets into the basket with a flourish, and then waves to the crowds. She whistles -
- and jumping from the carriage window comes a dog in a s coat. She holds out her hands, he jumps into her arms.
No. Absolutely not. Under no circumstances are we taking a dog.
I told you we’d need to put ona show for takeoff, and the crowd prefers my dog to your boxes. She indicates the scientific instruments being loaded int the balloon.
These are essential meteorological instruments.
The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 9 AMELIA makes eyes at one of the men holding the balloon d they nod at her authoritatively, she nods back.

And this is an essential dog. She’s called Posey. The essential Posey. She puts Posey down, and he enters the basket through a little opening in the side. The crowd cheer. JAMES grimaces. She pulls herself from his arms onto the edge of the ball She balances along the edge, all nimble beautiful energy. raises her hands in the air. The crowd whoop. She is astonishing. She raises her hands again for silence.
Ladies and Gentlemen. Today myself - Amelia Wren - my naughty scientist Mr. Glaisher - and my wonder dog Posey - are going to change the world. Are you ready for us to do so? There are loud cheers.

This balloon on which I stand - the Mammoth - is a balloon like no other and will allow us to ascend higher into the air than any man or woman has ever gone. She raises her hands in the air. The crowd laugh and chee again. She looks out in the crowd and sees a man she recognises: PIERRE. She looks at him a moment and then controls herself.

The French rose to 23,000 feet. Today, we will break their record and reclaim it for these fair shores. Who knows, we may reach the moon and bring back star dust! (beat) Today is a day when history will be made - and you will all be part of it. (to Glaisher) Mr Glaisher, now’s your moment. Up you get. There are yet more cheers. AMELIA pulls JAMES upwards, so too balances on the basket. AMELIA raises both her hands the air. On cue, FIREWORKS go off around the park.
The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 10 Brilliant sparkling eruptions of colour surround the amphitheatre. The crowd ROAR.
JAMES looks around at them all - a bemused smile on his f whilst AMELIA quickly and efficiently checks the rigging valves surrounding the basket.
Fireworks?
Are you ready?

I just need to retake my ground readings and then a final check of the equipment.... She counts the sand bags, she checks the appendix and fin she checks the valve line. She’s fast, precise and magnificently efficient.
Well, my equipment was all prepared in advance. Now, don’t touch that rope, Mr Glaisher - it’1ll let out the gas.
I do know how a balloon works. She signals to the men on the ground - who let go of the ropes and kick out the stakes.
What are you doing?
We fly.

Ground readings are essential - if they’re not accurate, then everything I take from now on - The balloon rises up. JAMES looks around, slightly bewildered, he starts desperately to take temperature and pressure readings.

The sky awaits. AMELIA takes a handful of sand and deposits it off the si of the balloon which falls to the floor beneath.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 11 There’s a moment of stasis and then - with a jerk and a c or two - the balloon begins to rise up. Slowly at first, with gathering speed. It’s majestic.

God speed, old man. JOHN TREW calls up to the basket. But JAMES GLAISHER does even notice him, he’s too intent on getting his notations down. The crowd watch in wonderment as the Mammoth silently ascends. Amongst them we pick out the face of CHARLIE.
400ft. Rising 400ft/min. 25C / 77F AMELIA has a business-like air that we haven’t seen befor She pulls herself up onto the netting on the side of the balloon.
What are you doing?

Giving the people their money's worth. She leans out and waves, the crowd cheer. The balloon ris to sixty feet and then a hundred. THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE wat from below, all with their faces turned upward to the sky She climbs further up the side of the balloon.
Won’t you damage the integrity of the balloon?
Perhaps. She pulls a cord on the side of her dress and the feather fall from it from all sides leaving her half the size.

This is insane. The feathers twinkle down in the wind, and are gathered enthusiastically by the crowd below. She leans out further, keeping good hold of the netting a she does, but she leans too far, she loses her grip, and suddenly SLIPS -  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 12
No! She SCREAMS - and then spins athletically around the hoop smiles. The crowd cheer below.
For God's sake.
It’s what they call entertainment, Mr Glaisher.
Well, I’m not finding it particularly entertaining.
Yes, it requires a sense of humour. Which you seem to..lack. She hangs nonchalantly in the air, her arms outstretched, welcoming the applause, her smile wider still.
Oh, don’t look so sour. The dog. Give me the dog.
What do you mean give you the dog?
Pass me Posey, Mr. Glaisher.
I’m not handing you the dog. JAMES wrestles with this notion.

Posey, now. Before we lose them. He scrabbles around in the basket for the dog. Eventually he’s able to grab POSEY and passes the dog up her. But as he does, she lets POSEY slip from her grasp. She screams and he hollers out in astonishment - as the d plummets past him, falling towards the earth with a yelp, looks down after it - anguished - and then the dog’s parachute opens. A parachute? The crowd cheer ever louder. She smiles.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 13 She spins round on the hoop and kisses the air extravagan JAMES looks at her - unsure what has happened here, but s he doesn’t like it.
Oh, well done Posey! Well done. She watches as POSEY is caught in NED’s arms below and th breathes in a tremendous breath, she is high on exhilarat She sees JAMES looking up at her. *

Mr Glaisher, you are airborne for the first time in your life, I suggest you spend less time frowning at me and more taking in the world we’ve just left. JAMES looks down and suddenly it seems all of London is l out below.
1,200ft. Rising 400ft/min. 23C / 73F AMELIA looks at JAMES, she smiles quietly at his astonishment.

(soft) Quite something isn’t she? London. When we’re further up, we’ll be able to see across to Windsor and down to Brighton. With current bearing, we should end up somewhere south of Canterbury. But anything is possible in this weather.
JAMES says nothing. AMELIA looks at him a moment more and then is a hive of energy balancing their equipment. From entertainer to businesswoman in two short breaths.
It all looks so -
Insignificant? With one final look down, she pulls herself down to the basket, flashes him a smile and then turns back to her equipment.
Do you take anything seriously? JAMES shakes his head.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 14
Those people gathered to see an act of science, to witness us break the height record, they didn’t need to see a flying dog.
Still stuck there, are you? AMELIA pulls her sleeves down and starts to take her make off.
I have spent much of my life being laughed at for what I do Miss Wren, I did hope today of all days might prove an exception. He returns to his books. She watches him carefully.
Tell me, what determines your reputation?
My reputation?
Your standing in the scientific community? JAMES frowns, considering sincerely.
I am aware what reputation means. The papers I’ve written, the discoveries I’ve uncovered.

Your reputation is built on paper. My reputation is built on screams. Those people below came to be entertained. And they - if you didn’t know - are the ones paying for this trip. JAMES looks at her, then shakes his head, as he takes a p of opera-glasses out of a pocket in the side of the baske
Off to the opera? He ignores her and uses the glasses to look up at the sky the darkening clouds - he frowns, but then dismisses his worry.  10 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 15
Don’t try and pretend that cloud isn’t a concern.
I am the scientist. You’re the pilot Miss Wren. Let’s stick to our roles shall we? He looks down at Greenwich Observatory, hundreds of feet below.
A younger JAMES GLAISHER is climbing fast up a sloping ro wearing a large shoulder bag. He is being pursued by JOHN TREW.
JAMES. James.
I will not miss this, John. JAMES opens a window, climbs out of it and is gone.

For God's sake. JOHN makes a face to himself. And then cursing his better nature, crawls up the roof after his friend. JOHN TREW (CONT’D) It is in the air, we could have stayed on the ground and looked up.
We must see it from the best vantage point, Johnny. JAMES pulls himself onto the roof. JOHN a few windows behind him, with one more despairing l to the ground, pulls himself after.
JOHN lies flat on the roof, panting deeply. Bells can be heard striking in the distance. JAMES turns towards them with a smile.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 16

The sky is clear. I predict a clean take-off. Which means in precisely sixteen seconds precisely we should see.... JAMES unpacks his shoulder bag - revealing within it a la telescope and then a stand to place it upon.
You are aware he might not get off the ground? He fits the telescope into the stand.
Charles Green will get it off the ground. He moves the stand to the very edge of the building. JOHN sees plaster crumble away.
Maybe not quite so close to the edge of the building.
John, stop scowling at me. Do I clock the hours I spend helping you pin butterflies to a board?
Pinning butterflies is not a dangerous pursuit.
Five, four, three, two, one. There’s a long pause. JAMES slowly deflates, JOHN looks a his friend with sympathy.
It could be anything. The gas valve ruptured, the silk tore - JAMES smiles as suddenly - clear as a day across London, balloon starts to rise up. JAMES looks at JOHN with the largest of smiles.
He has rethought his balloon shape. Wider at the top, like a parachute.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 17
May I look? JAMES reluctantly lets JOHN look through. JOHN looks intently.
Mr Trew, if you’ve had time enough... JOHN steps away with a smile, JAMES retakes his perch. And then thinks and then lifts the equipment and repositi himself towards the outside of the building.
He’s broken cloud. He refocuses the telescope.
I’ve lost him. He looks up to the sky. He squints. JOHN TREW looks at hi friend.
You’1ll get your chance you know. They'll realise your worth.
I think they know what I’m worth well enough.
JAMES GLAISHER stands at a lectern, in front of him assor scientists.

We know more now about the world around us than we have at any time in history, but still we are limited by our ignorance as to what is truly above us. With the progress we have made in balloon travel here at the Society, pioneered by Charles Green, we could advance meteorology by decades. Analysis of the Earth’s magnetic field, the solar spectrum, knowledge of the dew point, an understanding of oxygenation of the atmosphere...  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 18
He wants my balloon! Laughter breaks out again.
No sir, I want funding for my own expedition into the skies -
We are scientists, not fortune tellers! You talk of weather prediction. There’s laughter. JAMES rides over it.
Is that not our responsibility as scientists - to bring order to the chaos...

- if we can understand what’s - you are no closer to above us -— predicting the movements of the weather than the movements of a frog in a jar. He makes to walk out of the lecture theatre, others follo
With your financial support I believe we are on the precipice of great change - the possibility of advance weather prediction might allow for - He sees them all departing.
Please - please - 10c EXT. ROYAL SOCIETY. DAY 10c JAMES stands in the courtyard alone, as snow falls all ar him.

text: James's father, ARTHUR GLAISHER is reading a newspaper article.
“James Glaisher spoke this week at the Royal Society of his plans to make a science of the weather. -  10Ab 11 The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 19
I’ve read it, Pa.
“To the accompaniment of much laughter, he laid out -”
Arthur. Stop it.
They're wrong, by the way.
Many more think you are.
Many didn’t believe Newton.

Oh, James. Newton changed the way we saw the Earth and the planets. You think you can predict when it might rain. JAMES takes the bullet. He holds hard to his dignity. ARTHUR GLAISHER (CONT’D) What they say about you - it doesn’t hurt?
I wish it didn’t hurt you. EXT. WATCH SHOP. DAY 10Ab JAMES walks away from the shop. He looks up back at his father’s window.

5,700ft. Rising 400ft/min. 18C / 64F We re-join Wren & Glaisher, high above London, as they dr upward towards the thick cloud bank above them. WREN is dressing herself thoroughly in warm weather gear. sort of precursor to flying leathers. She does so discreetly, and JAMES makes sure to look away. She’s striking, practical and in control - she knows what is coming. JAMES, still in his wool suit, continues to take his measurements.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 20
Nine minutes and sixteen seconds. Height 5,700 feet. Air temperature, 64 degrees Fahrenheit.
How delightful. (motioning to her corset) Could you? He awkwardly helps her to undo her corset. She takes it o and puts on her jacket.
You should put on your oilskins, Mr Glaisher. Ignoring her, he writes something on a piece of paper. He ties it to a pigeon and lets it go, it flies shakily a and then down.
What are you attaching to those pigeons?
Our readings.
Oh, so reassuring to know you've contemplated our deaths.
Just - insured against them. AMELIA looks at him, she frowns, amused, but this time sh doesn’t challenge him, she looks up at the dark sky above them.
Cloud ahoy.
6,100ft. Rising 400ft/min. 15C / 59F The balloon is swallowed by the heavy, still clouds, and AMELIA looks over the edge so the earth disappears from v
What more felicitie can fall to creature Than to enjoy delight with libertie,  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 21
And to be lord of all the workes of Nature, She turns and sees PIERRE with his back to her, looking o at the clouds. She smiles.
To raine in th’aire from earth to highest skie, To feed on flowres and weeds of glorious feature. She approaches PIERRE, he turns, and it’s - JAMES.
To take whatever thing doth please the eye. AMELIA looks at him - astonished. He smiles shyly.
Spenser. The Fate of the Butterfly. One of my favourite poems. AMELIA swallows, dealing with her complicated emotions.
Surprising. Didn’t have you down as a literary man.
Men of science can enjoy words, Miss Wren.
My husband loved that poem. Beat. JAMES tries to retain his dignity.
I would have liked to have met your husband.
I’m not sure he'd have liked you.
Really?
He disliked people who studied rather than practiced. JAMES takes the dig as he reaches out and feels the air o his fingers. A roll of THUNDER.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 22
We are still sure this weather will hold - because my instinct tells me
Instinct has no place in weather prediction.
- that you’re lying to me.
Every reading I took this morning -
And there are no advantages in concealing concerns - we’re trapped here no matter what you say. JAMES thinks and then looks at her. He looks back at his measuring apparatus.
The air pressure is - changing faster than I anticipated. There is a flash of LIGHTNING - AMELIA turns towards it a JAMES scans the sky - truly concerned now.
Your readings were wrong. We are about to get wet.

Quiet. He holds out a hand. He’s listening for something else. W wait with him - the silence is powerful and oppressive. AMELIA looks at her hands. Moisture is clinging to her gloves. There is another rumble of THUNDER.

You're discerning how close we are to the storm. JAMES says nothing - clearly panicked, he turns to his equipment and consults numbers in his book. Suddenly the balloon JOLTS. The balloonists grab the side of the baske Then there is calm again. AMELIA looks to the West and th East. She smiles.

And so it begins.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 23 EXT. SKY. CONTINUOUS -— 13 We’re in a pocket amongst the cumulonimbus clouds. We lin on the churning sky. Lightning illuminates hidden crevices. A rapidly shifting and darkening landscape. We see moving through it - the Mammoth.
7,200ft. Rising 400ft/min. 10C / 50F And then we’re back inside the balloon. JAMES is taking readings.

We need to batten down. He takes out his Spectroscope. He twirls it around. He ma notes in his book. AMELIA WREN (CONT’D) I’m not sure your instruments are much use to us now. JAMES looks at her, and then checks the hygrometer.
There are no prizes for obstinacy. James — THUNDER. They both turn towards it.
If you won’t listen to me. Listen to that.
Not one of my readings suggested a storm -

Well that’s what it is, and we’re inside a cumulo, which is precisely where we shouldn’t be. He takes more readings. He’s more skittery now, less focu She sees another flash of LIGHTNING. A roll of THUNDER on seconds later.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 24
Don’t worry, The Mammoth is not made of conductive material - we won't attract lightning.
And if we do, the gas keeping us afloat is fifty per cent hydrogen, thirty-five percent methane, so we won’t live long enough for me to point out how wrong you were...

7,600ft. Speed of ascent constantly changing. 9C / 48F Suddenly both balloonists are THROWN to the floor, an agitation in the air causes a WHIRLWIND - which turns the giant balloon three times from the right to the left. There is another SMASH OF LIGHTNING closer to the balloon this time, and with it comes the RAIN. Rain which lashes down and which seems to suggest worse. JAMES returns to his instrumentation, writing down a seri of readings.
Get that equipment put away now -

The equipment will give us the information we need to survive this They are THROWN again, violently this time, horrifically time. JAMES is slammed into the side of the basket. AMELIA hauls him to the floor and uses her legs to pincer into position -

Stay still and keep calm - I need to get us out of here. And then they are THROWN again - and this time JAMES is thrown on top of AMELIA, smashing his head on the pigeon in the process. BLOOD pours from the wound.
We cannot descend - this may be our one and only opportunity -
Of course we don’t descend.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 25 JAMES looks at her, shocked.
We don’t?

There are two ways to break a storm. One is to travel beneath it, the other - to travel above it. The safest way is up. Another fork of LIGHTNING STRIKES. The THUNDER ROARS immediately afterwards. AMELIA looks across at JAMES - a smile spreads across his face.
The safest way is up?

Who did you think you got ina balloon with? AMELIA smiles and then pulls off her wet and slippy glove and grabs a knife from her small bag and leans over the s of the balloon - seemingly immune to the raging storm - t slice off some bags of ballast.

9,000ft. Falling 4000ft/min, then rising 600ft/min. 7C / Then the balloonists hit a pocket of cold air and the bal suddenly DROPS 1000 FEET. This has the effect of sending AMELIA and JAMES and everything that isn’t bound to the basket of the balloon in the air. JAMES’s leg hits the underside of the table o his way up, BREAKING IT and sending his equipment everywh We watch almost in slow motion the detritus float away - gloves arcing gracefully out of the balloon and away. AMELIA and JAMES hit the underside of the balloon, bounce off, and fall back towards the basket again. JAMES lands HARD in the basket, but AMELIA misses the bas clawing desperately at the wicker as she does. JAMES look for her but everything is obscured by the mist. He’s blin

Amelia! Amelia. AMELIA’s legs dangle helplessly in space. She clings to t rope that holds the grapnel, the rain LASHING around her.  The AERONAUTS Cut Order - As of 20th July 2019 26 The mist clears and her perilous position becomes very cl She's on the verge of oblivion. Then the mist returns and blindness is intoxicating. JAMES grabs a central rope and reaches out a hand -

Take my hand. Take my hand. He grabs at one of the toggled ropes holding the basket t the hoop, but in quick succession three of the TOGGLES SN and the balloon is massively destabilized, everything tum towards him as the basket falls into a slant. This loosen AMELIA’s grip and she falls further. Screaming as she doe
I can’t - I can’t get...
Hold on. HOLD ON. He grabs another rope, then quickly ties a rope around hi waist and secures the other end to the hoop above his hea He steels himself - overcomes his fear - and leans out.

On three. One. Two. They grab hands. They dangle for a moment, him holding her as firmly as he can. And then he starts heaving her back into the balloon. She scrabbles up, gets a foothold. It’s hard. The rain continues to lash their faces. AMELIA manoeuvres way upwards. She lands beside him in the bottom of the basket, both BREATHING DEEPLY.

9,600ft. Rising 600ft/min, then 1000ft/min. 5c / 41F As the storm buffets around them, AMELIA pulls a ROPE nex JAMES, releasing a sandbag which plummets into the cloud. She pulls another ROPE on her side of the basket: another of ballast FALLS.
